results.title: I Still know what you did last summer
results.creator_credit: Danny Cannon, Neal H. Moritz and Global Entertainment Productions
results.brief_description: Producer of “I know what you did last summer” Neal H. Moritz commented that “I Know” was positioned perfectly with the success of “Scream”, “Party of five” and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer.” Its sequel, “I still know what you did last summer,” without such support in its marketing campaign, was left to prove itself in a sea of teen horror films, all trailing in the wake of “Scream.” “I Still know” reunites us with our heroine, Julie James (Jennifer Love Hewitt), at university, far away from Southport where the horrors of last summer (and the summer before that), took place. The nightmares of the meat-hook-wielding fisherman are preventing Julie from putting the brutal murder of her best friend, Helen (Sarah Michelle Gellar), behind her. Luckily, Julie has made a new best friend, Karla (Brandy), who has won a trip to the Bahamas and convinces Julie to go with her and some other friends. They arrive only to discover that it’s the off-peak season and, with the exception of ‘marginally trained off-season staff’, they are alone on the island. Julie’s nightmares become a reality upon discovering the fisherman is on the island seeking his revenge. Julie is forced to fess up to her friends about her tormented past as they struggle for their lives knowing they are caught in total isolation. Refreshingly, “I Still know” has subscribed to the new paradigm of teen horror, whereby the protagonist teen character is given personality and a surname. With a supporting cast that is less disposable than the teenager characters of slasher films of the past, “I Still know” is more suspenseful and more frightening, and a horror film that can stand on its own merit. Cast includes: Jennifer Love Hewitt, Brandy, Freddy Prinze Jr., Mekhi Phifer, Muse Watson.

results.title: Whore
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell, Dan Ireland, Ronaldo Vasconcellos and Trimark Pictures
results.brief_description: Whore tells the story of one night in the life of a prostitute. Liz, (Theresa Russell) is a street wise hooker who has seen it all and done it all. In contrast to “Pretty Woman”, this film does not glamorise prostitution. This is a brash, vulgar depiction of the profession. Although exploitative and titillating in itself, it does raise issues often overlooked in more romantic interpretations, including legalisation, safe sex, drug abuse and the relationship between sex and power.

results.title: The Ring within [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Dan Bigras, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Dan Bigras, Canadian singer and filmmaker, features in his own documentary along with his extreme fighter friends, Charles Ali Nestor (27 y.o.), David Loiseau (21 y.o.) and Steve Vigneault (22 y.o.) to demonstrate that an outlet can be found for those who find themselves battling with self-destructive impulses or overwhelming uncontrollable anger and rage. Where Bigras uses singing and song-writing as his outlet, his friends prefer to channel their energies into martial arts and extreme fighting as a way of rebuilding their lives. It would seem a common thread runs through the lives of each of these young men as they tell their stories of an unhappy childhood, bullying, teenage gangs, violence and family break-down. But the frankness and honesty in their personal tales and the friendship, loyalty and support between the four men in their collective struggle to transform their anger into a rage for life is what really defines this film, not the fighting scenes - their courage is to be admired. Features interviews with families, friends, sporting personnel and other extreme fighters and includes graphic coverage of bouts from competition fights and training sessions. In English and French with English subtitles. WARNING: CONTAINS GRAPHIC IMAGES OF EXTREME FIGHT SCENES.

results.title: More Winners : His Master's Ghost
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Margaret McDonald and Steve Steve Jodrell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
A vacation music camp at an old country estate brings together a group of children, not all of whom have come with music foremost in their minds. The estate has an air of mystery about it and when mention is made of a live-in ghost, some of the children, especially Flea, become fascinated. Flea’s obsession in tracking down the ghost and playing practical jokes leads him into constant trouble with the teachers. Meanwhile, Jason, a rather serious boy is, against some purist opposition, trying to get his Concerto for the Rock Group and Orchestra, which has a very difficult solo passage, played in the final concert. Between these two stories floats the estate’s caretaker, a figure of mystery and fascination. Rated: G

results.title: More Winners : Second Childhood
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Jane Ballantyne and Mario Andreacchio
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners”.
At school, Mark meets Annie who believes she is the reincarnation of Australia’s most famous racehorse - Phar Lap. Mark is fascinated by the concept of being someone else and becomes convinced he is the reincarnation of Henry Ford. His friends at school also get into the act believing they were Queen Victoria and Albert Einstein. At first they revel in their new identities especially when a major new school assignment is to research the life of a prominent historical figure. When their research reveals that their past lives were collectively responsible for quite a few of the world’s current problems, the children set out on a daring mission to make up for what they have done. Rated: G

results.title: More Winners : Boy Soldiers (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mark Joffe, Margot McDonald and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
In 1910, the Australian Government passed a law requiring all boys aged between 14 and 17 years to register for compulsory military training. Between 1910 and 1915, more than 30,000 boys were prosecuted for failing to obey this law. This story tells of one such boy, Will Barnes, a 14 year old conscientious objector who refuses to register. After prosecution Will is sentenced to 3 months training at Fort Queenscliff. At the fort, Will refuses to wear a uniform or be involved in any type of military training. Will meets a lot of opposition, but also wins his share of admirers for sticking to his beliefs.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Joffe, Margot McDonald and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: More Winners : The Big Wish (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
In the Enchanted Realm the fairies are in trouble. According to the Charter of the Grand Master, they must give away seven wishes to the humans every 100 years or lose their magic powers. But the only human who will believe in them is Christopher Walter Pratt (C.W.). C.W. has one day to enjoy his seven wishes - what he doesn’t know is that the last wish lasts forever.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Esben Storm, Antonia Barnard and Australian Children’s Television Foundation

results.title: More Winners : His master's ghost (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Steve Steve Jodrell, Margot McDonald and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
A group of children are brought together to holiday at a music camp. set at an old estate, rumoured to have its own live-in ghost. One of the children, Flea, becomes obsessed with tracking down the phantom. Meanwhile Jason is attempting to get his Concerto for Rock Group and Orchestra approved of. During all this, strange things begin to happen whenever the estate’s mysterious care-taker is around.

results.title: More Winners : Second Childhood (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Mario Andreacchio, Jane Ballantyne and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
At school Mark meets Annie who believes she is the re-incarnation of Phar Lap. Soon Mark becomes fascinated by reincarnation and discovers he was Henry Ford in a past life. His friends also get into the act, and soon they are all revelling in their new “old” identities. But when they work out that in their past lives they were responsible for some of the world’s current problems, they set out on a mission to make up for what they’ve done.

results.title: More Winners : The Journey
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation, Richard Mason and Jane Oehr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘More Winners’.
Justus Zukermann, a wealthy prospector, lives with his 12 year old daughter, Ada on a windswept mountain plateau. Since Ada’s mother died, Martha and her step-daughter, Agnes, have been employed to run the household. One day Justus is fatally injured in a fall. Before he dies he orders Ada to journey south to find her true inheritance. Agnes is to accompany her. Martha (who is in fact a witch) has for years envied Justus’ wealth. She determines to secure the hidden fortune for herself and orders Agnes to kill Ada and steal the map once they reach the forest. Agnes is unable to kill Ada and the two girls are drawn together. After several adventures the girls find a secret cave, unearth the buried treasure and a letter from Justus, which makes the purpose of their journey very clear. Rated: G
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation, Richard Mason and Jane Oehr
